statement.tex: \\ \text{Which column in the table below}\textbf{ (A or B)}\\ \text{shows the anti-derivatives?}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline f(x) & A & B \\ \hline 3\sqrt{x} & 2x\sqrt{x} & \frac{3}{2}\sqrt{x} \\ \hline \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} & 2\sqrt{x} & -\frac{1}{2x\sqrt{x}} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

reason.tex: \text{The }\textbf{derivative}\text{ of g(x) is a function that}\\ \text{represents the rate of change of g(x).} \\ \text{But the }\textbf{anti-derivative}\text{ of g(x) is a}\\ \text{function whose rate of change is g(x) itself.}\\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = g(x) \text{ or }\int g(x)\cdot dx = f(x)

\text{Notice that }\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}(2x\sqrt{x}) &= \dfrac{d}{dx}2x^{\frac{3}{2}} = 2\cdot\dfrac{3}{2}\cdot\sqrt{x} = 3\sqrt{x} \\ \text{and }\dfrac{d}{dx}2\sqrt{x} &= 2\cdot\dfrac{1}{2}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x}} \end{align} \\ \text{Hence, the anti-derivatives are in }\textbf{column A}.\\ \text{And so, the anti-derivative of }\left(3\sqrt{x} + \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right) \\ \text{is simply }2x\sqrt{x} + 2\sqrt{x} = 2\sqrt{x}\cdot(x+1).
